all.title: Unstructured Data Objects
all.text: Unstructured data objects are data objects without a predefined structure, making them difficult to manage conventionally. Examples include text documents, images, audio and video...
all.longText: Unstructured data objects are data objects without a predefined structure, making them difficult to manage conventionally. Examples include text documents, images, audio, video, social media posts, and emails.

all.title: Vector
all.text: Vectors, or vector embeddings in databases, are quantities with magnitude and direction...
all.longText: Vectors, or vector embeddings in databases, are quantities with magnitude and direction represented by an array of numerical values. They represent data objects in multi-dimensional space.

all.title: Vector Embedding
all.text: Numerical representations of objects, such as words or images, in a vector space...
all.longText: Numerical representations of objects, such as words or images, in a vector space. These representations capture semantic relationships and are used in machine-learning tasks.

all.title: Embeddings Model
all.text: An algorithm or model that transforms objects (like words) into vector embeddings...
all.longText: An algorithm or model that transforms objects (like words) into vector embeddings. This enables capturing contextual and semantic information.

all.title: Vector-Based Index
all.text: A vector index is a type of data structure for efficiently storing high-dimensional vector data...
all.longText: A vector index is a type of data structure for efficiently storing high-dimensional vector data generated by machine learning models. Its main purpose is facilitating quick and accurate similarity searches, using algorithms like trees or hashing to reduce complexity in high-dimensional spaces.

all.title: Vector Database
all.text: A vector database indexes, stores, and provides access to structured or unstructured data...
all.longText: A vector database indexes, stores, and provides access to structured or unstructured data (e.g., text or images) alongside itsÂ vector embeddings, which are the data's numerical representation. It allows users to find and retrieve similar objects quickly at scale in production.

all.title: HNSW
all.text: HNSW (Hierarchical Navigable Small World) is a graph-based vector indexing method for...
all.longText: HNSW (Hierarchical Navigable Small World) is a graph-based vector indexing method for efficient approximate nearest neighbor searches. It organizes data in a multi-layer structure, enabling fast and accurate queries by navigating through layers from coarse to fine granularity.

all.title: Sparse Vectors
all.text: Sparse embeddings are generated from algorithms like BM25 and SPLADE...
all.longText: Sparse vectors are often high-dimensional with many zeros. Sparse embeddings are generated from algorithms like BM25 and SPLADE. These algorithms are used in keyword-based search to represent text documents.

all.title: Dense Vectors
all.text: In contrast to sparse vectors, dense vectors contain mostly non-zero values and are generated from machine learning models like GloVe and Transformers...
all.longText: In contrast to sparse vectors, dense vectors contain mostly non-zero values and are generated from machine learning models like GloVe and Transformers. These vectors capture the semantic meaning of text and are used in vector search techniques.

all.title: BM25/BM25F
all.text: BM25 is a ranking function used by search engines to estimate the relevance of documents to a given search query. It is part of the family of probabilistic information retrieval models...
all.longText: BM25 is a ranking function used by search engines to estimate the relevance of documents to a given search query. It is part of the family of probabilistic information retrieval models. BM25F is a variant of BM25 that can handle fields with different weights, such as title and body in documents.

all.title: Alpha Parameter
all.text: This is an optional parameter in hybrid search queries that determines the weighting of each search algorithm during the re-ranking process...
all.longText: This is an optional parameter in hybrid search queries that determines the weighting of each search algorithm during the re-ranking process. An alpha value of 0 gives full weight to the sparse vector (BM25), 1 gives full weight to the dense vector, and 0.5 gives equal weight to both.

all.title: Fusion Algorithm
all.text: In hybrid search, the fusion algorithm combines results from keyword and vector searches into a final list of ranked search results...
all.longText: In hybrid search, the fusion algorithm combines results from keyword and vector searches into a final list of ranked search results. A popular fusion algorithm is called reciprocal ranked fusion, which uses the sum of the inverse of the position of the results. There are multiple types of fusion algorithms. Weaviate supports reciprocal rank fusion and relative score fusion.

all.title: Hybrid Search
all.text: Hybrid search in Weaviate combines keyword (BM25) and vector search to leverage both exact term matching and semantic context...
all.longText: Hybrid search in Weaviate combines keyword (BM25) and vector search to leverage both exact term matching and semantic context. It uses rankedFusion or relativeScoreFusion algorithms to merge results, providing a balance between precision and semantic understanding.

all.title: Keyword Search
all.text: Keyword search finds objects with an exact match between the terms in the query and in the documents...
all.longText: Keyword search finds objects with an exact match between the terms in the query and in the documents. Weaviate uses the BM25/F function to calculate the relevancy of a document to a query, which uses both the term frequency and inverse document frequency.
all.blogTitle2: A Web Developers Guide to Hybrid Search

all.title: Semantic/Vector Search
all.text: Semantic search, also known as vector search, uses machine learning to grasp text context, not just keywords...
all.longText: Semantic search, also known as vector search, uses machine learning to grasp text context, not just keywords. It converts text to numerical vectors, finding matches based on conceptual similarity for accurate, relevant search results.

all.title: Hierarchical Graph Structure
all.text: HNSW utilizes a multi-layered graph structure where each layer is a graph of the data points. The top layers contain fewer points with long-range connections...
all.longText: HNSW utilizes a multi-layered graph structure where each layer is a graph of the data points. The top layers contain fewer points with long-range connections, and as you go down the layers, the number of points increases, and the connections become more local. This hierarchical structure allows for efficient navigation during search queries.

all.title: ANN - Approximate Nearest Neighbor
all.text: ANN algorithms calculate the approximate nearest neighbors to a query, as opposed to kNN algorithms, which calculate the true nearest neighbors...
all.longText: ANN algorithms calculate the approximate nearest neighbors to a query, as opposed to kNN algorithms, which calculate the true nearest neighbors. ANN algorithms enable the quick and efficient identification of the closest data points at scale. This makes ANN suitable for big data where speed matters more than perfect accuracy.
all.blogTitle: Why is Vector Search so Fast?

all.title: Layered Navigation
all.text: During a search, HNSW starts at the topmost layer and makes 'big jumps' across the graph to quickly move closer to the target region...
all.longText: During a search, HNSW starts at the topmost layer and makes 'big jumps' across the graph to quickly move closer to the target region. As it moves down the layers, the search becomes more refined, with smaller, more local jumps until the nearest neighbors are identified in the bottom layer.

all.title: Graph-Based Index
all.text: HNSW is a graph-based indexing technique, meaning that it organizes the data points in a graph structure rather than traditional tree-based or hash-based structures...
all.longText: HNSW is a graph-based indexing technique, meaning that it organizes the data points in a graph structure rather than traditional tree-based or hash-based structures. This graph-based approach is key to its performance in high-dimensional vector space searches.
all.blogTitle: Why is Vector Search so Fast?

all.title: Cross Modal Reasoning
all.text: Cross-modal reasoning refers to the ability to make connections by integrating information from different modalities or sources including text, images, audio and video...
all.longText: Cross-modal reasoning refers to the ability to make connections by integrating information from different modalities or sources including text, images, audio and video. It involves leveraging knowledge from one modality to understand or reason about data from another modality.

all.title: Multimodal Embeddings Models
all.text: Multimodal Embeddings Models produce a joint embedding space for multimodal data that understands text, images, audio and more...
all.longText: Multimodal Embeddings Models produce a joint embedding space for multimodal data that understands text, images, audio and more. Objects that are similar are closer together and dissimilar objects are farther apart, this means that the model preserves semantic similarity within and across modalities.

all.title: Multimodal Contrastive Finetuning
all.text: Multimodal Embeddings Models produce a joint embedding space for multimodal data that understands text, images, audio and more...
all.longText: Multimodal Embeddings Models produce a joint embedding space for multimodal data that understands text, images, audio and more. Objects that are similar are closer together and dissimilar objects are farther apart, this means that the model preserves semantic similarity within and across modalities.

all.title: Any-to-any Search
all.text: In any-to-any search we can pass in as a query any modality the model understands and use it to perform vector similarity search...
all.longText: In any-to-any search we can pass in as a query any modality the model understands and use it to perform vector similarity search in multimodal embedding space, getting back objects of any other modality that are similar in concept.

all.title: Multimodal RAG
all.text: Multimodal RAG involves retrieving from a multimodal knowledge base and then generation using a large multimodal model by...
all.longText: Multimodal RAG involves retrieving from a multimodal knowledge base and then generation using a large multimodal model by generating text or images grounded in the retrieved context, which can include images, text, audio, and other modalities.

all.title: Graph Database
all.text: A graph database stores data in nodes and edges, representing entities and their relationships. It's optimized for...
all.longText: A graph database stores data in nodes and edges, representing entities and their relationships. It's optimized for querying connections and patterns within the data, making it powerful for network, social, and recommendation systems.

all.title: Inverted Indexes
all.text: An inverted index is a database indexing structure that maps keywords to their locations in documents...
all.longText: An inverted index is a database indexing structure that maps keywords to their locations in documents, enabling fast full-text searches by listing all documents containing a given word, optimizing retrieval times. In Weaviate, it's used for keyword searches and fast filtering.

all.title: Sharding
all.text: Sharding is splitting a database into smaller, faster, more easily managed parts called shards...
all.longText: Sharding is splitting a database into smaller, faster, more easily managed parts called shards. Each shard is a self-contained unit with a subset of data, allowing for distribution across servers or data centers for improved performance and scalability.

all.title: Multi Tenancy
all.text: With multi-tenancy, a single database instance serves multiple clients or 'tenants'...
all.longText: With multi-tenancy, a single database instance serves multiple clients or 'tenants' simultaneously, while ensuring that each tenant's data remains isolated and secure. It also enables efficient resource use and cost savings over large datasets at scale.

all.title: Relational Database
all.text: A relational database organizes data into tables linked by relationships...
all.longText: A relational database organizes data into tables linked by relationships, enabling complex queries like finding students with both cats and dogs. It uses SQL for structured, precise data management, optimizing operations like filtering and joining for efficient data retrieval.

all.title: PQ
all.text: Product quantization (PQ) is a compression technique for vectors, reducing memory usage by...
all.longText: Product quantization (PQ) is a compression technique for vectors, reducing memory usage by up to 90%. It's a lossy algorithm, meaning it trades some accuracy for significant memory savings. However, Weaviate employs a rescoring technique to reduce the loss of recall.

all.title: Large Language Model (LLM)
all.text: A Large Language Model (LLM) is a machine learning model that is trained on vast text data, learning language...
all.longText: A Large Language Model (LLM) is a machine learning model that is trained on vast text data, learning language patterns to understand, predict and generate human-like text. It statistically models language to uniquely generate responses to queries with learned context.

all.title: Finetuning
all.text: Fine-tuning is a process where a pre-trained machine learning model is further trained on a specific dataset...
all.longText: Fine-tuning is a process where a pre-trained machine learning model is further trained on a specific dataset to specialize its knowledge or skills for a particular task or domain. This improves the model's performance on the related task while being more cost-efficient than training it from scratch.

all.title: Multi-modal
all.text: Multi-modal learning involves integrating various data types like images, text, audio, and sensory inputs...
all.longText: Multimodal learning involves integrating various data types like images, text, audio, and sensory inputs to create models that understand and process information like humans, recognizing patterns and context across different modes for different types of use-cases, like e-commerce.

all.title: Embedding model
all.text: An embedding model, or vectorizer, transforms text or images into vector embeddings, capturing semantic...
all.longText: An embedding model, or vectorizer, transforms text or images into vector embeddings, capturing semantic meaning through statistical analysis, converting conceptual significance into numerical representations.

all.title: Chunking
all.text: Chunking is the process of dividing large texts into smaller, manageable pieces, called 'chunks'...
all.longText: Chunking is the process of dividing large texts into smaller, manageable pieces, called 'chunks', for storage or processing in vector databases and language models. It improves search performance and the quality of language model outputs by defining the granularity of information retrieval.

all.title: Generative AI
all.text: Generative AI is a type of artificial intelligence powered by generative machine learning models that produces new...
all.longText: Generative AI is a type of artificial intelligence powered by generative machine learning models that produces new and original outputs like images, text, audio, or video based off user provided prompts or input.
all.blogTitle: Hurricane: Writing Blog Posts with GFL

all.title: Transformer Model
all.text: A transformer model is a type of neural network architecture designed to handle sequential data, like text, for tasks such...
all.longText: A transformer model is a type of neural network architecture designed to handle sequential data, like text, for tasks such as translation and question-answering. It's efficient and scalable, using attention mechanisms to weigh the importance of different parts of the input data.

all.title: Reranking
all.text: Re-ranking is adjusting the scores of search results after initial retrieval. It usually uses a machine learning model...
all.longText: Re-ranking is adjusting the scores of search results after initial retrieval. It usually uses a machine learning model to reassess the relevance between the query and each result, refining the scores to improve accuracy and relevance for the user or an LLM's task. It's like a second quality check.

all.title: Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG)
all.text: Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG) is the process of contextualising prompts for large language models...
all.longText: Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG) is the process of contextualising prompts for large language models (LLMs) by leveraging available data in a store allowing an LLMs to ingest relevant information that guides their predictions.

all.title: Variable Dimensions
all.text:
Flexible embedding sizes, like Matryoshka embeddings.
Encode information hierarchically, allowing adaptation...
all.longText: Flexible embedding sizes, like Matryoshka embeddings. Encode information hierarchically, allowing adaptation to different tasks or computational constraints while preserving semantic meaning.

all.title: Sparse Embeddings
all.text: Sparse vectors are often high-dimensional with many zero values. They are generated from algorithms like BM25 and SPLADE...
all.longText: Sparse vectors are often high-dimensional with many zero values. They are generated from algorithms like BM25 and SPLADE and are used in keyword-based search.

all.title: Quantized Embeddings
all.text: Compressed dense vectors using lower-precision data types (e.g., float32 to int8). Reduces memory usage and speeds up search...
all.longText: Compressed dense vectors using lower-precision data types (e.g., float32 to int8). Reduces memory usage and speeds up search while maintaining most semantic information.

all.title: Multi-vector Embeddings
all.text: Usage of multiple vectors instead of one pooled vector  to represent e.g., token-wise embeddings (e.g., ColBERT)...
all.longText: Usage of multiple vectors instead of one pooled vector  to represent e.g., token-wise embeddings (e.g., ColBERT). Allows for more detailed representation of complex texts.
all.docTitle: How to use ColPali with Weaviate's Named Vectors!

all.title: Dense Embeddings
all.text: Dense embeddings contain mostly non-zero values and are generated from machine learning models like Transformers...
all.longText: Dense embeddings contain mostly non-zero values and are generated from machine learning models like Transformers. These vectors capture the semantic meaning of text and are used in semantic search.

all.title: Binary Embeddings
all.text: Extreme quantization, reducing vector components to binary (0 or 1) values. Drastically reduces memory use...
all.longText: Extreme quantization, reducing vector components to binary (0 or 1) values. Drastically reduces memory use.

all.title: Semantic Chunking
all.text: In this technique, the text is divided into meaningful units, such as sentences or paragraphs, which are then vectorized...
all.longText: In this technique, the text is divided into meaningful units, such as sentences or paragraphs, which are then vectorized. These units are then combined into chunks based on the cosine distance between their embeddings, with a new chunk formed whenever a significant context shift is detected.
all.videoTitle: Dive into Chunking Strategies for RAG with Zain

all.title: Recursive Chunking
all.text: Text is initially split using a primary separator, like paragraphs. If the resulting chunks are too large, secondary separators...
all.longText: Text is initially split using a primary separator, like paragraphs. If the resulting chunks are too large, secondary separators, like sentences, are applied recursively until the desired chunk size is achieved. This technique respects the document's structure and is flexible for various use cases.
all.videoTitle: Dive into Chunking Strategies for RAG with Zain

all.title: LLM-Based Chunking
all.text: This advanced technique uses a Language Model (LLM) to generate chunks. The LLM processes the text and generates semantically isolated sentences...
all.longText: This advanced technique uses a Language Model (LLM) to generate chunks. The LLM processes the text and generates semantically isolated sentences or propositions that can stand alone. While this method is highly accurate, it is also the most computationally demanding.
all.videoTitle: Dive into Chunking Strategies for RAG with Zain

all.title: Fixed Size Chunking
all.text: This technique splits the text into chunks of a fixed size, without considering natural breaks or the structure of the content...
all.longText: This technique splits the text into chunks of a fixed size, without considering natural breaks or the structure of the content. It's simple and cost-effective, but lacks contextual awareness. To improve this, overlapping chunks can be used, allowing adjacent chunks to share some content.
all.videoTitle: Dive into Chunking Strategies for RAG with Zain

all.title: Document-Based Chunking
all.text: This technique creates chunks based on the natural divisions within the document, such as headings or sections. It's very effective for structured data like HTML...
all.longText: This technique creates chunks based on the natural divisions within the document, such as headings or sections. It's very effective for structured data like HTML, Markdown, or code files but itâs less useful when the data lacks clear structural elements.
all.videoTitle: Dive into Chunking Strategies for RAG with Zain

all.title: Reasoning and Acting (ReAct)
all.text: ReAct prompting combines CoT with agents, creating a system where the model can generate thoughts and delegate actions to agents that interact with external data sources...
all.longText: ReAct prompting combines CoT with agents, creating a system where the model can generate thoughts and delegate actions to agents that interact with external data sources. ReAct enables LLMs to dynamically interact with retrieved documents, updating reasoning and actions based on external knowledge to provide more contextually relevant responses.

all.title: Tree of Thoughts (ToT)
all.text: Tree of Thoughts prompting builds on CoT by instructing the model to evaluate its responses at each step in the problem-solving process or even generate several different solutions to a problem...
all.longText: Tree of Thoughts prompting builds on CoT by instructing the model to evaluate its responses at each step in the problem-solving process or even generate several different solutions to a problem and choose the best result. This is useful in RAG when there are many potential pieces of evidence, and the model needs to weigh different possible answers based on multiple retrieved documents.

all.title: Chain of Thought (CoT)
all.text: Chain of Thought (CoT) prompting involves asking the model to âthink step-by-stepâ and break down complex reasoning tasks into a series of intermediate steps...
all.longText: Chain of Thought (CoT) prompting involves asking the model to âthink step-by-stepâ and break down complex reasoning tasks into a series of intermediate steps. This can be especially useful when retrieved documents contain conflicting or dense information that requires careful analysis.

all.title: Data Cleansing
all.text: Data cleaning and noise reduction involves removing irrelevant information (such as headers, footers, or boilerplate text), correcting inconsistencies, and handling missing values...
all.longText: Data cleaning and noise reduction involves removing irrelevant information (such as headers, footers, or boilerplate text), correcting inconsistencies, and handling missing values while maintaining the extracted data's structural integrity.

all.title: Data Extraction and Parsing
all.text: Data extraction and parsing convert raw data into an LLM-ready format. Text-based files retain structure, while OCR handles scanned docs...
all.longText: Data extraction and parsing convert raw data into an LLM-ready format. Text-based files retain structure, while OCR handles scanned docs. Advanced multimodal models may replace OCR by embedding images directly. HTML parsing, spreadsheet handling, and metadata extraction refine the process for efficiency.

all.title: Data Transformation
all.text: Data Transformation involves converting all processed content into a standardized schema regardless of original file type...
all.longText: Data Transformation involves converting all processed content into a standardized schema regardless of original file type. It is at this stage that document partitioning occurs, separating document content into logical units or elements (e.g., paragraphs, sections, tables).
